statement.text: The saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ) is the highly variable termination point of the small saphenous vein (SSV), classically into the popliteal vein but absent in 20-30% of limbs where the SSV drains via the Giacomini vein to the GSV instead. Preoperative ultrasound mapping of SPJ location is mandatory.
statement.formal: SPJ_Location: Popliteal_Fossa, 3-7cm above knee crease (variable); Present in 70-80%, Absent in 20-30% (Giacomini drainage)

explanation.intuition: If the GSV termination (SFJ) is like a predictable highway interchange, the SPJ is more like a country road junction that might be in a different place in every county. You cannot assume where it is - you must map it with ultrasound before any procedure.
explanation.key_insight: The key clinical implication of SPJ variability is that preoperative ultrasound mapping is MANDATORY. Unlike the SFJ which is consistently 2-4cm below the inguinal ligament, the SPJ can be at knee level, mid-thigh, or completely absent (Giacomini drainage). Treating the SSV without knowing where it terminates risks incomplete treatment or injury to popliteal structures.
explanation.technical_details: The SPJ classically forms where the SSV enters the posterolateral aspect of the popliteal vein in the popliteal fossa. The terminal valve lies within 1-2cm of the junction. The Giacomini vein, when present, is a cranial extension of the SSV that courses posteromedially in the thigh to join the GSV. In 20-30% of limbs, this is the primary SSV drainage (no true SPJ). Variations include termination into gastrocnemius veins, femoral vein, or profunda femoris vein.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: The SPJ is always at the popliteal crease. Reality: SPJ height varies from the crease to mid-thigh; it may be absent entirely.
Misconception: SSV treatment is similar to GSV. Reality: SPJ variability and sural nerve proximity make SSV treatment more complex.
Misconception: If no SPJ is found, the SSV doesn't need treatment. Reality: Giacomini drainage is an alternative; treat the Giacomini if refluxing.

anatomic_location.depth: Deep to popliteal fascia in popliteal fossa

giacomini_drainage.description: SSV continues cranially as Giacomini vein to GSV
giacomini_drainage.significance: No true SPJ exists; treat Giacomini if refluxing

gastrocnemius.significance: May be associated with gastrocnemius vein reflux

high_termination.description: Enters femoral vein in distal thigh

giacomini_vein.definition: Intersaphenous vein connecting SSV to GSV
giacomini_vein.course: Posterior-medial thigh from SSV to posteriomedial GSV
clinical_significance: Alternative SSV drainage when no true SPJ
Route for reflux propagation between SSV and GSV
Must be identified and treated if incompetent

neural_relationships.sural_nerve: Runs with SSV below mid-calf; converges at SPJ level
neural_relationships.tibial_nerve: Deep to popliteal vessels in fossa
neural_relationships.injury_risk: Sural nerve injury is major complication of SPJ surgery

presentation: Posterior calf or popliteal fossa varicosities
diagnosis: Measure SPJ height from popliteal crease
Mark SPJ location on skin preoperatively
treatment: Prone or lateral positioning for access
Tumescent anesthesia for thermal ablation (nerve protection)
Foam sclerotherapy alternative for smaller veins

definition.@value: The anatomic termination point of the small saphenous vein, typically into the popliteal vein but highly variable in location and occasionally absent when drainage occurs via the Giacomini vein instead.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
Journal of Vascular Surgery: Venous and Lymphatic Disorders
sources.article: Saphenopopliteal junction anatomy: Systematic review and meta-analysis

learning_objectives: Describe SPJ anatomic location and common variations
Identify Giacomini vein and its clinical significance
Apply preoperative duplex mapping requirements for SSV treatment
Recognize neural structures at risk during SPJ procedures
clinical_pearls: True SPJ into popliteal vein exists in only 70-80% of limbs
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV - treat if incompetent
ALWAYS ultrasound map SPJ before treatment - location is HIGHLY variable
SPJ height ranges from popliteal crease to mid-thigh
Sural nerve injury is major complication - use tumescent for thermal ablation

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
